One of the things that really I found interesting about this documentary was that you and the director, Dawn Logsdon, were filming and had no idea at the time that you were filming, that what you were capturing in the community was going to be reduced to shambles by Hurricane Katrina.
There were also were some questions about whether or not your own material was going to survive, weren't there?
We managed to get back into the city roughly a week after the storm because our tapes had been saved in a vault.
But there was no power in the city, which mean that there were basically cooking in that vault and the longer they stayed there, the less likely they were to be useful.

So we got back in and got the material, but we also realized that while we could not make the movie we intended to make before the storm, we had what could be a far more powerful movie, because we had people that we'd been following literally for years and now had an opportunity to see how they'd been affected by this tragedy.
Dawn's idea was as soon as possible, to meet these people back in the city and get their stories, their post-Katrina stories.
One of those people was the carpenter who was helping you, as I understand it, with the restoration of your home but lost his own home as a result of Katrina.
Yeah.
Mr. Treviene(ph) was a carpenter who actually was the great-great grandnephew of the editor of the first black daily newspaper in America, the New Orleans Tribune.
And so in meeting him, we realized we had found someone who both lived the history and could tell it because free people of color had dominated the building trades for literally generations.
And we found with Mr. Treviene is that he knew those stories and he knew that history, but of course like so many other people he had moved to a low area of town.
He was still in a not - he was still in the city proper, but a whole lot of us found out when the federal levies failed that the area we thought was safe was not as safe as we had believed.
Do you remember the day that you walked in to his - well it wasn't even - well it was his home before Katrina, it was what's left of his home when you guys went in there for the first time.
I remember that day well.
Mr. Treviene had moved to Vermont to be with his daughter and granddaughter.
So they drove back to see the house, and even before we went in the house he noticed that his truck had been flooded and that his tools were gone.
And it was difficult to get into the house because the door had been swollen by the water.
You have to understand; at this point Mr. Treviene was in his late 70's.
This is a man who is used to building houses and repairing houses, and had been a younger man that might have been a challenge to him.
But as an older man who was basically retired before the storm, this was an insurmountable challenge and so much of his story is the story of elderly New Orleanians.
When I looked at his face, it looked literally as if the life just seeped out of it.
That was the feeling that we got sitting there.
After he had gone into the house, we sort of sat there and kind of cleaned up a little bit and talk, but there wasn't a whole lot to say.
And he didn't live much longer did he?
No.
He was - he went back to Vermont, discovered that he had cancer, and dying probably six or eight months after that.

One of the things that is very difficult to convey to outsiders is the extent to which heartbreak played such a physical, tangible role in people's decline after the storm, and that certainly people had ailments that may have been bothering them even before the storm, but it seemed that the psychological and emotional toll of the failure of the levees really was that much more exacerbated.

You find people who may have had blood pressure problems all their lives suddenly dying of stokes, and we in New Orleans believe firmly that that was because of the pressures brought about as a result of the hurricane and the failure of the levees.
Is that why some people refer to this documentary as a requiem?
Indeed.
I mean, we like to refer to it more as a love poem for the city because much of what we really focus on is not the storm at all.
A lot of it is to tell you about how important this neighborhood was, to give you some sense of what it feels like to be in the middle of a street parade in the Faubourg Treme.
Give you a sense of what our musicians are dealing with and talking about.
Give you some sense of what people are writing about.
We hesitate to call this a Katrina film.
It really is a love poem to New Orleans.
